ground_truth: Mildred cuts in to dance with Edward, but it's hard to hear over the music. Edward stops dancing, and after a brief moment, he heads for the edge of the crowd, walking down Main Street. The townspeople stop dancing, disbelieving and some shaking their heads, saying poor Edward Bloom's gone crazy. Jenny runs to him and would tackle him if she could, but Edward keeps walking. In various shots, Edward negotiates the thorns in his bare feet, which is horrible and almost unendurable, and then it gets worse. The trees ahead are moving, and at first it just seems to be the wind blowing the branches, but as the wood cracks and groans, it's unmistakable: they're trying to block him. Snake-like white roots shoot out of the ground, grabbing for his ankles. He leaps up, kicking off one tree trunk to grab another one's branches and swings off, lands, and rolls. Now all the trees are moving to block him, towering over him in the flashes of lightning. As he ducks under branches, the chain holding the Key to the City gets caught, and he's almost strangled, but the chain finally breaks, and the silver key disappears into the mud. Scrambling forward, he looks for a way out, but the trees have encircled him, their spiky crowns bending down to crush him. He screams up at the night until his breath is gone. With a sudden calm, another lightning flash occurs, and suddenly the trees are back where they've always been. Edward is lying shoeless and torn in a muddy puddle, staring up at the rain and laughing. His bare foot steps onto asphalt, and Edward turns to see to his right, a larger, paved road. Edward looks down at his muddy, bloody feet, and with that, the men start walking down the larger road. Edward and Will sit at opposite ends of the table, with Sandra and Josephine in the middle. Although Edward has a small plate of food in front of him, he hasn't touched it. He's exhausted from the trip downstairs but determined to maintain the family dinner ritual. The other three eat awkwardly, each clink and scrape of a knife or fork resonating. Will finally breaks the silence, and as Will scoops out another serving of potatoes, Edward suddenly speaks, and all three stop to listen. She smiles. He tries to recollect, but it's already gone. Josephine motions, asking if it’s okay for her to sit on the bed, and he nods. She shakes her head, and a long beat passes. Then, deadpan, Edward rolls his eyes, why not. Josephine leaves, heading down the hall to get her camera. We stay with Edward in bed as he grimaces, a flash of pain showing that around others he's hiding how much it hurts, but alone it's clear how bad it is.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Mildred interrupts to dance with Edward, but it's difficult to hear over the melody. Edward ceases dancing, and after a fleeting instant, he heads for the perimeter of the throng, strolling down Main Street. The townsfolk cease dancing, incredulous and some shaking their heads, saying unfortunate Edward Bloom's gone insane. Jenny rushes to him and would tackle him if she could, but Edward continues walking. In various scenes, Edward maneuvers the thorns in his bare feet, which is dreadful and nearly unbearable, and then it becomes worse. The trees ahead are shifting, and at first, it just seems to be the breeze blowing the branches, but as the wood creaks and groans, it's unmistakable: they're trying to obstruct him. Serpentine white roots shoot out of the earth, grasping for his ankles. He jumps up, kicking off one tree trunk to grab another one's limbs and swings off, lands, and rolls. Now all the trees are shifting to obstruct him, looming over him in the flashes of lightning. As he ducks under boughs, the chain holding the Key to the City gets trapped, and he's almost choked, but the chain finally snaps, and the silver key disappears into the muck. Scrambling forward, he seeks a path out, but the trees have surrounded him, their spiky crowns bending down to crush him. He yells up at the sky until his breath is gone. With an abrupt calm, another lightning flash occurs, and suddenly the trees are back where they've always been. Edward is lying shoeless and torn in a muddy puddle, staring up at the rain and laughing. His bare foot steps onto pavement, and Edward turns to see to his right, a broader, paved road. Edward looks down at his muddy, bloody feet, and with that, the men begin walking down the broader road. Edward and Will sit at opposite ends of the table, with Sandra and Josephine in between. Although Edward has a small dish of food in front of him, he hasn't touched it. He's weary from the journey downstairs but resolved to uphold the family dinner tradition. The other three eat awkwardly, each clink and scrape of a knife or fork resonating. Will finally breaks the silence, and as Will scoops out another serving of potatoes, Edward suddenly speaks, and all three pause to listen. She smiles. He tries to recall, but it's already vanished. Josephine gestures, asking if it’s okay for her to sit on the bed, and he nods. She shakes her head, and a long pause ensues. Then, deadpan, Edward rolls his eyes, why not. Josephine departs, heading down the corridor to get her camera. We remain with Edward in bed as he winces, a flash of pain showing that around others he's concealing how much it hurts, but alone it's clear how severe it is.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Mildred cuts in to dance with Edward, but it's hard to hear over the music. The dancing is stopped by Edward, and after a brief moment, the edge of the crowd is headed for by him, walking down Main Street. The townspeople, disbelieving and some shaking their heads, say poor Edward Bloom's gone crazy and stop dancing. Jenny runs to him and would tackle him if she could, but Edward keeps walking. With various shots, the thorns are negotiated by Edward in his bare feet, which is horrible and almost unendurable, and then worse things happen. The trees ahead are moving, and at first, they just seem to be blown by the wind, but as the wood cracks and groans, it's unmistakable: they try to block him. Snake-like white roots shoot out of the ground, grabbing for his ankles. He leaps up, kicking off one tree trunk to grab the branches of another one, swings off, lands, and rolls. Now he is blocked by all the moving trees, towering over him in the flashes of lightning. As he ducks under branches, the Key to the City chain gets caught, and he is almost strangled, but the chain finally breaks, and the silver key disappears into the mud. Scrambling forward, a way out is looked for by him, but the trees have encircled him, their spiky crowns bending down to crush him. The night is screamed up at by him until his breath is gone. With a sudden calm, another lightning flash occurs, and suddenly the trees are back where they've always been. A muddy puddle is lain in by Edward, shoeless and torn, staring up at the rain and laughing. His bare foot steps onto asphalt, and Edward turns to see a larger, paved road to his right. He looks down at his muddy, bloody feet, and with that, the larger road is started down by the men. Edward and Will sit at opposite ends of the table, with Sandra and Josephine in the middle. Although a small plate of food is in front of him, Edward hasn't touched it. Exhaustion from the trip downstairs affects him but determination to maintain the family dinner ritual is shown by him. The other three eat awkwardly, each clink and scrape of a knife or fork resonating. The silence is finally broken by Will, and as another serving of potatoes is scooped out by him, Edward suddenly speaks, and all three stop to listen. She smiles. He tries to recollect, but it's already gone. Josephine motions, asking if it’s okay for her to sit on the bed, and he nods. She shakes her head, and a long beat passes. Then, deadpan, his eyes are rolled by Edward, why not. Josephine leaves, heading down the hall to get her camera. We stay with Edward in bed as he grimaces, a flash of pain showing that around others, the extent to which it hurts is hidden by him, but alone it's clear how bad it is.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Mildred cuts in to dance with Edward, but the music is too loud. Edward stops and heads for the crowd's edge, walking down Main Street. Townspeople stop dancing, disbelief evident as some shake their heads, saying poor Edward Bloom's gone crazy. Jenny runs to him, unable to stop him, as Edward navigates the thorns barefoot, nearly unbearable pain escalating. The trees ahead move; initially, it's just wind, but cracking and groaning confirm they're blocking him. Snake-like roots grab his ankles. He leaps, kicks off one tree to swing to another, lands, and rolls. The trees tower over him in lightning flashes, branches ensnaring the Key to the City chain, almost strangling him, until it breaks, key vanishing in the mud. Encircled by trees, Edward screams until breathless. Suddenly calm, lightning flashes again, trees return to normal. Edward lies shoeless in a muddy puddle, laughing in the rain. His bare foot hits asphalt, spotting a larger paved road to the right. Seeing his muddy, bloody feet, he starts down the road. Edward and Will sit at opposite ends of the table, Sandra and Josephine between. Though Edward has food, he hasn't touched it, exhausted but committed to family dinner. The others eat awkwardly, cutlery sounds echoing. Will breaks the silence; as he serves more potatoes, Edward suddenly speaks, halting everyone. She smiles, but he can't recall. Josephine signals to sit on the bed; he nods. She shakes her head, pauses, then deadpan, Edward rolls his eyes. Josephine leaves for her camera. Edward grimaces alone, revealing hidden pain.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Mildred cuts in to dance with Edward, but the music is too loud. Edward stops, heads for Main Street, and the townspeople watch, disbelieving, saying he's gone crazy. Jenny runs to stop him, but Edward continues, navigating painful thorns barefoot. The trees ahead move, seemingly wind-blown, then unmistakably block him. Snake-like roots grab his ankles, but he leaps and rolls, dodging moving branches. The Key to the City chain catches, almost strangling him, but breaks, losing the key in the mud. Trapped by tree crowns, he screams until exhausted. Calmly, a lightning flash returns the trees to normal. Edward lies shoeless, laughing in a puddle, then steps onto asphalt, finding a larger road. Later, Edward sits exhausted at the dinner table with Will, Sandra, and Josephine. Exhaustion and pain make him avoid eating, but he maintains the family dinner. Will breaks the silence, Edward speaks, and all listen. Josephine gestures to sit on the bed; Edward nods. She leaves for her camera. Alone, Edward grimaces, revealing his hidden pain.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Mildred, with a determined look in her eyes, steps in to dance alongside Edward, though the music's volume makes it challenging to hear her. Edward ceases his dancing abruptly, and after a moment’s pause, he gravitates toward the edge of the lively crowd, making his way down Main Street with purpose. The townspeople, caught off guard, stop their own dancing, displaying disbelief, while some shake their heads in dismay, murmuring among themselves about how poor Edward Bloom must have lost his mind. Jenny, filled with urgency, rushes towards him, desperate to stop him if she could physically intervene, but Edward continues his march undeterred. 

In a series of shots, Edward finds himself negotiating a path through the thorn-laden underbrush with his bare feet, a journey that proves both excruciating and almost impossible to endure, only to find it getting progressively worse. At first, the trees ahead seem to sway solely due to the wind's force, but as the wood around him begins to crack and groan ominously, it becomes unmistakably clear that they're genuinely trying to impede his progress. Snake-like, pale roots snake out from the earth below, reaching out with intent to entangle his ankles. With agility, he leaps into the air, using one tree trunk as a springboard to grasp the branches of another, swinging himself off, landing deftly, and rolling away. All around him, the trees animate fully, moving to prevent his escape, their towering forms illuminated sporadically by flashes of lightning. As he ducks beneath encroaching branches, the chain bearing the cherished Key to the City becomes ensnared, nearly strangling him, but thankfully, it breaks away, and the silver key vanishes into the murky mud. 

Pushing forward with urgency, Edward seeks an escape route, but he finds himself enclosed by the trees, their spiked crowns bending menacingly to crush him. In a moment of desperation, he screams out into the consuming night until his breath completely escapes him. Then, with a sudden, unexplainable calmness, another lightning flash lights up the scene, revealing that the trees have returned to their original, immobile positions. Edward, battered and without shoes, finds himself lying in a pool of mud, staring up into the falling rain, and unexpectedly, he begins to laugh. His bare feet touch the asphalt, and Edward turns his gaze to his right, seeing a wider, paved road extending ahead. He looks down at his muddy, bloodied feet, and with a resigned determination, starts to walk down the larger road. 

Later, Edward and Will are seated at opposing ends of the dining table, with Sandra and Josephine positioned between them. Although a small plate of food sits untouched before Edward, indicating his lack of appetite, he's determined to uphold the cherished family dinner tradition despite the exhausting trek downstairs. The other three family members eat in an awkward silence, every clink and scrape of utensils echoing sharply in the quiet room. Eventually, Will breaks the silence with conversation, and as he serves himself another portion of potatoes, Edward unexpectedly begins to speak, prompting all three to halt and listen intently. She smiles gently, and Edward searches his memory for something that's already slipped away. Josephine gestures, seeking his permission to sit on the bed beside him, and he nods in consent. She shakes her head slightly, and after a prolonged pause, Edward, with a hint of exasperation, rolls his eyes as if to say, "Why not?" 

Josephine departs, heading down the hallway to retrieve her camera. We remain with Edward as he lies in bed, concealing a wince as a flash of pain betrays his true condition, revealing how much he suffers alone, despite his efforts to hide it among others.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Mildred, her eyes full of a determined fire, steps into the dance area to join Edward, even though the music's overwhelming volume makes it incredibly difficult for her to be heard. Edward suddenly halts his dancing quite abruptly, and after a brief moment's hesitation, he begins to move deliberately toward the edge of the vibrant, bustling crowd. With clear intent, he starts making his way down the main artery of the town, Main Street, with a purposeful stride. The townspeople, taken entirely by surprise, cease their own dancing, their faces painted with disbelief. A few among them shake their heads in dismay, muttering quietly to one another, pondering whether poor Edward Bloom has indeed lost his sanity. Jenny, filled with a pressing sense of urgency, rushes toward him, eager and desperate to stop him if she could only find a way to physically intervene, but Edward continues his determined march, entirely undeterred by her plea.

In a sequence of compelling shots, Edward is seen navigating his way through the thorn-laden, dense underbrush with his uncovered feet—a journey that proves both agonizing and nearly impossible to endure, becoming progressively more difficult with every step. Initially, the trees ahead appear to sway merely due to the natural force of the wind, but as the forest around him begins to ominously creak and groan, it becomes unmistakably evident that the trees themselves are actively trying to hinder his progress. Root-like tendrils, pale as snakes, slither from the earth beneath him, reaching out with the intent to ensnare his ankles. With nimble agility, he leaps into the air, using the trunk of one tree as a makeshift springboard to grasp the branches of another. He swings himself off, landing gracefully, and expertly rolls away. All around him, the trees fully animate, moving purposefully to block his escape, their towering forms sporadically illuminated by dramatic flashes of lightning. As he ducks and dodges beneath the creeping branches, the chain holding the treasured Key to the City becomes entangled around him, nearly strangling him. Fortunately, it breaks away, allowing the silver key to disappear into the dark, murky mud below.

Moving forward with a sense of urgency, Edward searches frantically for an escape route, only to find himself enclosed and trapped by the trees, their spiked crowns bending threateningly, intent on crushing him. In a moment of sheer desperation, he cries out into the oppressive, consuming night until all his breath flees from him. Then, with an abrupt and inexplicable calmness, another flash of lightning illuminates the scene, revealing that the trees have returned to their original, unmoving positions. Edward, battered and barefoot, discovers himself lying in a pool of thick mud, staring up into the pouring rain. Unexpectedly, he begins to laugh. His bare feet touch the solid asphalt, and Edward turns his gaze to his right, noticing a wider, more expansive paved road stretching out in front of him. He looks down at his muddy, bloodied feet, and with a sense of resigned determination, he begins to walk along the larger road.

Later, Edward and Will find themselves seated at opposite ends of the dining table, with Sandra and Josephine positioned between them. Although a small plate of food rests untouched in front of Edward, subtly indicating his lack of appetite, he remains determined to uphold the cherished family dinner tradition, despite the exhausting effort of coming downstairs to join them. The other three family members eat in an awkward silence, every clink and scrape of utensils echoing sharply in the otherwise quiet room. Eventually, Will decides to break the silence with conversation, and as he serves himself another generous portion of potatoes, Edward suddenly starts to speak, prompting all three to stop and listen intently. She smiles gently, and Edward searches his memory, striving to recall something that has already slipped away. Josephine makes a gesture, seeking his permission to sit on the bed beside him, and he nods in agreement. She shakes her head slightly, and after a prolonged pause, Edward, with a hint of exasperation, rolls his eyes as if to say, "Why not?"

Josephine departs from the room, proceeding down the hallway to retrieve her camera. We remain with Edward as he lies in bed, subtly concealing a wince as a flash of pain betrays just how much he truly suffers, revealing the depth of his condition, despite his efforts to hide it when surrounded by others.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Mildred weaves through the crowd, cutting in to join Edward for a dance. The music blares loudly, making it difficult for them to hear each other over the pulsating rhythms. Edward pauses his dancing abruptly, standing still momentarily as he takes in the scene around him before deciding to make his way towards the outskirts of the crowd. He navigates his way through the throng, reaching Main Street, where he begins walking purposefully. The townspeople, witnessing his departure, cease their own dancing, their faces a mixture of disbelief and concern. Some shake their heads in disapproval, murmuring to one another about poor Edward Bloom's seemingly irrational behavior. Jenny, filled with urgency, rushes toward him, her intent clear in her determined stride, wishing she could stop him in his tracks. Despite her efforts, Edward maintains his pace, continuing his walk undeterred. In a series of glimpses, Edward is shown negotiating the thorn-covered ground with his bare feet, each step an exercise in endurance amidst the unbearable pain. The situation takes a turn for the worse as the trees ahead appear to animate, initially swaying as if caught by a strong gust of wind. However, as the wood begins to crack and emit groaning sounds, it becomes unmistakable that they are intentionally obstructing his path. Snake-like white roots sprout from the ground, viciously reaching for his ankles. In a desperate bid for freedom, Edward propels himself upwards, using one tree trunk as leverage to launch himself toward the branches of another. He grasps the branches with a firm grip, swings through the air, lands with a thud, and rolls across the forest floor. The trees around him, now fully animated, maneuver to block his escape, towering ominously above him, highlighted sporadically by flashes of lightning. As he attempts to evade the grasping branches, the chain holding the Key to the City becomes ensnared, tightening dangerously around his neck, near-strangling him until it snaps, sending the silver key plummeting into the mud below. Scurrying forward, he searches frantically for a way out, but the trees have formed an impenetrable circle around him, their sharp crowns threatening to descend and crush him. With no other options, he unleashes a primal scream into the night sky, continuing until he is breathless. Suddenly, a strange calm washes over him as another flash of lightning reveals the trees are once again stationary, restored to their former positions. Edward finds himself lying on the ground, shoeless and disheveled, amidst a muddy puddle. He gazes upwards, allowing the rain to wash over him, and inexplicably, he begins to laugh. Gathering himself, he steps onto the asphalt, the sensation of the cool surface grounding him. As he pivots, he notices a larger, paved road stretching out to his right. He glances down, taking in his muddy, bloodied feet, and with that realization, begins walking along the expansive road. In a different scene, Edward and Will are seated at opposite ends of a long dining table, with Sandra and Josephine occupying the seats in between. Although a small plate of food sits in front of Edward, he hasn't taken a bite. Weary from the effort it took to descend the stairs, he remains resolute in his commitment to the family dinner ritual. The others eat with a palpable awkwardness, the clinking and scraping of utensils against plates resonating loudly in the quiet room. Amidst the silence, Will eventually speaks up, and as he helps himself to another serving of potatoes, Edward's voice infiltrates the space, prompting all three to halt their actions and listen attentively. A smile graces her face as he attempts to recall something, only to find the memory has already slipped away. Josephine gestures, silently inquiring if it's acceptable for her to join him on the bed, and he acknowledges her with a nod. She responds with a shake of her head, and a lingering pause ensues. Then, with a deadpan expression, Edward rolls his eyes, conveying a resigned acceptance of the situation. Josephine exits the room, her form retreating down the hall in pursuit of her camera. The focus remains on Edward as he lies in bed, a grimace temporarily overtaking his features, betraying the intense pain he is valiantly concealing from others. In solitude, the severity of his discomfort becomes unmistakably clear.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description:
Mildred cuts in to dance with Edward, but the music is too loud to hear. Edward stops and heads toward the edge of the crowd on Main Street while townspeople react with disbelief, some shaking their heads and remarking on his supposed madness. Jenny tries to reach him but Edward continues on, navigating painful thorns barefoot. The situation intensifies as trees seem to move with intent, blocking his path with snake-like roots grabbing at his ankles. He leaps and swings between the trees, narrowly avoiding capture while losing the Key to the City in the process. Encircled and overwhelmed by the trees, he screams until he is out of breath. Suddenly, with a flash of lightning, the trees return to their normal state, leaving Edward shoeless and mud-covered in a puddle. Laughing, he notices a larger, paved road and begins walking on it.

Later, Edward and Will sit at opposite ends of a table, with Sandra and Josephine in the middle. Though Edward hasn't touched his small plate of food due to exhaustion, he insists on participating in the family dinner. The others eat awkwardly until Will breaks the silence, prompting Edward to speak, and everyone listens intently. After a brief exchange, Josephine gestures to sit on the bed, to which Edward consents. She leaves to get her camera as Edward, now alone, reveals the extent of his pain that he hides around others.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Mildred cuts in to dance with Edward, but it's hard to hear over the lively jazz music emanating from The Blue Note, the town's beloved music club. Edward stops dancing, and after a brief moment, he heads for the edge of the crowd, walking down Main Street, a historic road lined with century-old buildings. The townspeople stop dancing, disbelieving and some shaking their heads, saying poor Edward Bloom's gone crazy, remembering his reputation as the town's eccentric storyteller. Jenny, who has always believed in Edward's fantastical tales, runs to him and would tackle him if she could, but Edward keeps walking. In various shots, Edward negotiates the thorns in his bare feet, a remnant of the briar patch from his childhood fables, which is horrible and almost unendurable, and then it gets worse. The trees ahead are moving, and at first it just seems to be the wind blowing the branches, but as the wood cracks and groans, it's unmistakable: they're trying to block him, as if the enchanted forest from his stories had come alive. Snake-like white roots shoot out of the ground, grabbing for his ankles. He leaps up, kicking off one tree trunk to grab another one's branches in a move reminiscent of his youthful agility, and swings off, lands, and rolls. Now all the trees are moving to block him, towering over him in the flashes of lightning that illuminate the sky like a nightmarish dance. As he ducks under branches, the chain holding the Key to the City, a ceremonial honor he received for his contributions to the town, gets caught, and he's almost strangled, but the chain finally breaks, and the silver key disappears into the mud. Scrambling forward, he looks for a way out, but the trees have encircled him, their spiky crowns bending down to crush him. He screams up at the night until his breath is gone, evoking the desperation of a hero in a tragic tale. With a sudden calm, another lightning flash occurs, and suddenly the trees are back where they've always been, silent sentinels of the forest. Edward is lying shoeless and torn in a muddy puddle, staring up at the rain and laughing, as though he'd just survived an epic adventure. His bare foot steps onto asphalt, and Edward turns to see to his right, a larger, paved road known locally as Route 23. Edward looks down at his muddy, bloody feet, and with that, the men start walking down the larger road, the one leading out of town and towards new beginnings. Edward and Will sit at opposite ends of the table in the family dining room, with Sandra and Josephine in the middle. Although Edward has a small plate of his favorite shepherd's pie in front of him, he hasn't touched it. He's exhausted from the trip downstairs, a feat that has become increasingly difficult in recent days, but determined to maintain the family dinner ritual that he holds dear. The other three eat awkwardly, each clink and scrape of a knife or fork resonating in the quiet room. Will finally breaks the silence, and as Will scoops out another serving of potatoes from the family recipe handed down from Edward's mother, Edward suddenly speaks, and all three stop to listen. She smiles, offering Edward comfort in her quiet way. He tries to recollect the tale he was about to tell, but it's already gone, slipping away like so many of his memories have lately. Josephine motions, asking if it’s okay for her to sit on the bed, and he nods, grateful for her company. She shakes her head, and a long beat passes, the silence filled with unspoken understanding. Then, deadpan, Edward rolls his eyes, why not, inviting a moment of shared levity. Josephine leaves, heading down the hall to get her camera, hoping to capture a moment of this family time. We stay with Edward in bed as he grimaces, a flash of pain showing that around others he's hiding how much it hurts, but alone it's clear how bad it is, as the weight of his ailments bears down on him.

Edward stops dancing and after a brief moment he heads for the edge of the crowd walking down Main Street. The townspeople stop dancing disbelieving and some shaking their heads saying poor Edward Bloom's gone crazy. Jenny runs to him and would tackle him if she could but Edward keeps walking. With a sudden calm another lightning flash occurs and suddenly the trees are back where they have always been. Edward is lying shoeless and torn in a muddy puddle staring up at the rain and laughing. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. His bare foot steps onto asphalt and Edward turns to see to his right a larger paved road. Edward looks down at his muddy bloody feet and with that the men start walking down the larger road. Edward and Will sit at opposite ends of the table with Sandra and Josephine in the middle. Although Edward has a small plate of food in front of him he has not touched it. He is exhausted from the trip downstairs but determined to maintain the family dinner ritual. The other three eat awkwardly each clink and scrape of a knife or fork resonating. Will finally breaks the silence and as Will scoops out another serving of potatoes Edward suddenly speaks and all three stop to listen. She smiles. He tries to recollect but it is already gone. Josephine motions asking if it is okay for her to sit on the bed and he nods. She shakes her head and a long beat passes. Then deadpan. Edward rolls his eyes. why not. Josephine leaves heading down the hall to get her camera. We stay with Edward in bed as he grimaces a flash of pain showing that around others he is hiding how much it hurts but alone it is clear how bad it is.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: Mildred cuts in to dance with the wolf, but it's hard to hear over the music. The wolf stops dancing, and after a brief moment, the wolf heads for the edge of the crowd, walking down Main Street. The cats stop dancing, disbelieving and some shaking their heads, saying poor Edward Bloom's gone crazy. The rabbit runs to the wolf and would tackle the wolf if it could, but the wolf keeps walking. In various shots, the wolf negotiates the thorns in its bare feet, which is horrible and almost unendurable, and then it gets worse. The rocks ahead are moving, and at first it just seems to be the wind blowing the branches, but as the wood cracks and groans, it's unmistakable: they're trying to block the wolf. Snake-like white roots shoot out of the ground, grabbing for its ankles. The wolf leaps up, kicking off one tree trunk to grab another one's branches and swings off, lands, and rolls. Now all the trees are moving to block the wolf, towering over it in the flashes of lightning. As it ducks under branches, the chain holding the Key to the City gets caught, and it's almost strangled, but the chain finally breaks, and the silver key disappears into the mud. Scrambling forward, it looks for a way out, but the trees have encircled it, their spiky crowns bending down to crush it. The wolf screams up at the night until its breath is gone. With a sudden calm, another lightning flash occurs, and suddenly the trees are back where they've always been. The wolf is lying shoeless and torn in a muddy puddle, staring up at the rain and laughing. Its bare foot steps onto asphalt, and the wolf turns to see to its right, a larger, paved road. The wolf looks down at its muddy, bloody feet, and with that, the birds start walking down the larger road. The dragon and the bear sit at opposite ends of the table, with Sandra and Josephine in the middle. Although the dragon has a small plate of food in front of it, it hasn't touched it. It's exhausted from the trip downstairs but determined to maintain the family dinner ritual. The other three eat awkwardly, each clink and scrape of a knife or fork resonating. The bear finally breaks the silence, and as the bear scoops out another serving of potatoes, the dragon suddenly speaks, and all three stop to listen. She smiles. It tries to recollect, but it's already gone. Josephine motions, asking if it’s okay for her to sit on the bed, and it nods. She shakes her head, and a long beat passes. Then, deadpan, the dragon rolls its eyes, why not. Josephine leaves, heading down the hall to get her camera. We stay with the dragon in bed as it grimaces, a flash of pain showing that around others it's hiding how much it hurts, but alone it's clear how bad it is.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Mildred cuts in to dance with Edward, but it's hard to hear over the waves. Edward stops dancing, and after a brief moment, he heads for the edge of the garden, walking down Elm Avenue. The townspeople stop dancing, disbelieving and some shaking their heads, saying poor Edward Bloom's gone crazy. Jenny runs to him and would tackle him if she could, but Edward keeps walking. In various shots, Edward negotiates the cobblestones in his bare hands, which is horrible and almost unendurable, and then it gets worse. The bushes ahead are moving, and at first it just seems to be the breeze blowing the leaves, but as the bark cracks and groans, it's unmistakable: they're trying to block him. Vine-like black ropes shoot out of the earth, grabbing for his wrists. He leaps up, kicking off one fence post to grab another one's leaves and swings off, lands, and rolls. Now all the bushes are moving to block him, towering over him in the flashes of fireworks. As he ducks under leaves, the thread holding the Medal of Honor gets caught, and he's almost strangled, but the thread finally breaks, and the bronze medal disappears into the sand. Scrambling forward, he looks for a way out, but the bushes have encircled him, their thorny branches bending down to crush him. He screams up at the dusk until his breath is gone. With a sudden calm, another firework flash occurs, and suddenly the bushes are back where they've always been. Edward is lying gloveless and torn in a sandy puddle, staring up at the drizzle and laughing. His bare hand steps onto concrete, and Edward turns to see to his right, a larger, cobblestone path. Edward looks down at his sandy, bleeding fingers, and with that, the women start walking down the larger path. Edward and Will sit at opposite ends of the counter, with Sandra and Josephine in the middle. Although Edward has a tiny spoon of rice in front of him, he hasn't touched it. He's exhausted from the climb upstairs but determined to maintain the family breakfast ritual. The other three eat awkwardly, each clink and scrape of a spoon or ladle resonating. Will finally breaks the silence, and as Will scoops out another serving of peas, Edward suddenly speaks, and all three stop to listen. She frowns. He tries to recollect, but it's already gone. Josephine motions, asking if it’s okay for her to sit on the rug, and he nods. She nods her head, and a long beat passes. Then, deadpan, Edward rolls his eyes, why not. Josephine leaves, heading down the stairwell to get her sketchbook. We stay with Edward on the sofa as he grimaces, a flash of pain showing that around others he's hiding how much it hurts, but alone it's clear how bad it is.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Mildred bursts in to sing with Edward, but it's hard to smell over the music. Edward pauses singing, and after a brief moment, he skips to the edge of the crowd, jogging down Main Street. The townspeople pause singing, disbelieving and some shrugging their shoulders, saying poor Edward Bloom's gone adventurous. Jenny strolls to him and would cheer him if she could, but Edward keeps jogging. In various shots, Edward admires the clouds in his bare feet, which is delightful and almost thrilling, and then it gets calmer. The trees ahead are dancing, and at first it just seems to be the wind rustling the leaves, but as the wood creaks and whispers, it's unmistakable: they're trying to hug him. Snake-like white roots soar out of the ground, waving at his ankles. He jumps up, pushing off one tree trunk to tickle another one's branches and swings off, lands, and skips. Now all the trees are swaying to hug him, bowing over him in the flashes of lightning. As he reaches under branches, the chain holding the Key to the City gets caught, and he's almost tickled, but the chain finally snaps, and the silver key floats into the mud. Glancing forward, he searches for a way out, but the trees have gathered around him, their spiky crowns bending down to tickle him. He whispers up at the night until his breath is gone. With a sudden calm, another lightning flash appears, and suddenly the trees are back where they've always danced. Edward is lying shoeless and calm in a muddy puddle, staring up at the rain and giggling. His bare foot hops onto asphalt, and Edward turns to examine to his right, a larger, paved road. Edward glances down at his muddy, bloody feet, and with that, the men begin skipping down the larger road. Edward and Will sit at opposite ends of the table, with Sandra and Josephine in the middle. Although Edward has a small plate of food in front of him, he hasn't admired it. He's exhilarated from the trip upstairs but determined to maintain the family dinner ritual. The other three bicker awkwardly, each clink and scrape of a knife or fork resonating. Will finally mumbles the silence, and as Will spills out another serving of potatoes, Edward suddenly whispers, and all three freeze to listen. She smirks. He tries to recall, but it's already vanished. Josephine gestures, asking if it’s okay for her to stand on the bed, and he grins. She nods, and a long beat passes. Then, deadpan, Edward sighs, why not. Josephine remains, heading down the hall to get her journal. We stay with Edward in bed as he smiles, a flash of joy showing that around others he's hiding how much it lifts, but alone it's clear how good it is.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Percy cuts in to swim with Gertrude, but it's hard to hear over the fireworks. Gertrude stops swimming, and after a brief moment, she heads for the edge of the room, walking down Elm Avenue. The visitors stop swimming, disbelieving and some shaking their heads, saying poor Gertrude Reed's gone bananas. Martha runs to her and would hug her if she could, but Gertrude keeps walking. In various shots, Gertrude negotiates the gravel in her bare hands, which is horrible and almost unbearable, and then it gets worse. The fountains ahead are moving, and at first it just seems to be the breeze blowing the sprays, but as the water splashes and churns, it's unmistakable: they're trying to block her. Snake-like black shadows shoot out of the air, grabbing for her wrists. She leaps up, kicking off one fountain base to grab another one's cables and swings off, lands, and rolls. Now all the fountains are moving to block her, towering over her in the flashes of fireworks. As she ducks under sprays, the chain holding the Medal of Honor gets caught, and she's almost strangled, but the chain finally breaks, and the gold medal disappears into the fountain. Scrambling forward, she looks for a way out, but the fountains have encircled her, their watery jets bending down to soak her. She screams up at the sky until her breath is gone. With a sudden calm, another fireworks burst occurs, and suddenly the fountains are back where they've always been. Gertrude is lying shoeless and torn in a muddy puddle, staring up at the stars and laughing. Her bare hand steps onto grass, and Gertrude turns to see to her left, a larger, stone path. Gertrude looks down at her muddy, bloody hands, and with that, the children start walking down the larger path. Gertrude and Sam sit at opposite ends of the bench, with Maria and Jonathan in the middle. Although Gertrude has a small cup of tea in front of her, she hasn't touched it. She's exhausted from the trip upstairs but determined to maintain the neighborhood picnic ritual. The other three sip awkwardly, each clink and scrape of a spoon or fork resonating. Sam finally breaks the silence, and as Sam scoops out another serving of salad, Gertrude suddenly speaks, and all three stop to listen. He smiles. She tries to recollect, but it's already gone. Jonathan motions, asking if it’s okay for him to sit on the chair, and she nods. He shakes his head, and a long beat passes. Then, deadpan, Gertrude rolls her eyes, why not. Jonathan leaves, heading down the stairs to get his flashlight. We stay with Gertrude in bed as she grimaces, a flash of discomfort showing that around others she's hiding how much it hurts, but alone it's clear how bad it is.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Miriam jumps in to sing with Elbert, but it's hard to see over the crowd. Elbert starts singing, and after a brief moment, he rushes for the top of the hill, skipping down Main Street. The visitors start singing, disbelieving and some shaking their fists, saying poor Elbert Bloom's gone wild. Jenna skips to him and would hug him if she could, but Elbert keeps skipping. In various shots, Elbert navigates the pebbles in his bare feet, which is uncomfortable and almost unbearable, and then it gets tougher. The clouds above are churning, and at first it just seems to be the wind swirling the leaves, but as the wood groans and snaps, it's unmistakable: they're attempting to trap him. Rope-like black vines slither out of the earth, reaching for his knees. He jumps up, bouncing off one tree trunk to catch another one's vines and swings off, lands, and tumbles. Now all the trees are swaying to trap him, looming over him in the flashes of fire. As he slides under branches, the cord holding the Emblem of Honor gets tangled, and he's almost choked, but the cord finally snaps, and the bronze emblem disappears into the mire. Crawling onward, he searches for an escape, but the bushes have surrounded him, their jagged edges leaning in to trap him. He yells up at the moon until his strength is gone. With a sudden peace, another flash of lightning occurs, and suddenly the bushes are back where they've always stood. Elbert is lying barefoot and scratched in a muddy pool, staring up at the stars and chuckling. His bare toe steps onto concrete, and Elbert turns to notice to his left, a wider, cobblestone path. Elbert gazes down at his filthy, scuffed feet, and with that, the women start skipping down the wider path. Elbert and Walt sit at opposite ends of the bench, with Sally and Joanne in the center. Although Elbert has a tiny cup of tea in front of him, he hasn't sipped it. He's weary from the walk upstairs but resolved to uphold the family meal tradition. The other three sip awkwardly, each clink and tap of a mug or spoon echoing. Walt finally breaks the silence, and as Walt spoons out another portion of beans, Elbert suddenly tests his voice, and all three pause to listen. She giggles. He tries to remember, but it's already left. Joanne gestures, asking if it’s fine for her to lie on the couch, and he shrugs. She nods, and a quiet moment passes. Then, matter-of-factly, Elbert rolls his eyes, why indeed. Joanne departs, heading down the corridor to fetch her notebook. We stay with Elbert on the couch as he winces, a flash of discomfort revealing that around others he's masking how much it aches, but alone it's evident how severe it is.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Mildred interrupts the feast with Edward, but it's hard to see over the fireworks. Edward pauses feasting, and after a brief moment, he drifts toward the edge of the festival, gliding down Main Street. The townspeople pause feasting, disbelieving and some covering their mouths, saying poor Edward Bloom's gone wild. Jenny glides to him and would dive at him if she could, but Edward keeps gliding. In various shots, Edward navigates the feathers in his bare hands, which is eerie and almost intolerable, and then it gets stranger. The clouds ahead are shifting, and at first, it just seems to be the breeze swaying the leaves, but as the air whistles and echoes, it's unmistakable: they're trying to confuse him. Snake-like black vines shoot out of the sky, reaching for his wrists. He catapults up, springing off one cloud to grip another one's leaves and swings off, lands, and twirls. Now all the clouds are shifting to obscure him, looming over him in the streaks of thunder. As he ducks under leaves, the thread holding the Medal of Honor gets tangled, and he's almost suffocated, but the thread finally snaps, and the bronze medal vanishes into the fog. Floundering forward, he searches for an escape, but the clouds have enveloped him, their thorny peaks lowering to envelop him. He shouts into the dawn until his voice is spent. With a sudden tranquility, another thunderclap occurs, and suddenly the clouds are back where they've always hovered. Edward is lying glove-less and tattered in a foggy mist, gazing up at the drizzle and chuckling. His bare hand touches a cobblestone, and Edward turns to notice to his right, a broader, cobbled pathway. Edward gazes down at his misty, bruised hands, and with that, the figures begin to glide down the broader pathway. Edward and Will remain at opposite ends of the couch, with Sandra and Josephine between them. Although Edward has a tiny bowl of soup in front of him, he hasn't sipped it. He's drained from the flight upstairs but resolved to uphold the family gathering custom. The other three sip awkwardly, each clang and rustle of a spoon or napkin resonating. Will finally shatters the quiet, and as Will ladles out another portion of carrots, Edward suddenly utters, and all three pause to listen. She grins. He attempts to remember, but it's already vanished. Josephine gestures, asking if it’s acceptable for her to rest on the couch, and he nods. She shrugs, and a long pause ensues. Then, deadpan, Edward narrows his eyes, why not. Josephine departs, heading down the corridor to retrieve her telescope. We remain with Edward on the couch as he winces, a flash of agony revealing that around others he's masking how severe it aches, but alone it's evident how dire it is.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Gertrude interrupts the orchestra with Clarence, but it's hard to taste over the aroma. Clarence pauses conducting, and after a short interval, he sails for the tip of the parade, tiptoeing down Elm Avenue. The villagers pause conducting, astonished and some nodding their torsos, muttering poor Clarence Lake's gone bananas. Lisa sprints to him and would nudge him if she could, but Clarence keeps tiptoeing. In several angles, Clarence navigates the petals in his gloved hands, which is delightful and almost insufferable, and then it gets better. The bushes nearby are dancing, and at first, it just appears to be the breeze tossing the leaves, but as the foliage snaps and whispers, it's undeniable: they're attempting to allow him. Dragon-like black vines thrust out of the air, lunging for his wrists. He vaults up, bouncing off one boulder to snatch another one's leaves and swings away, lands, and tumbles. Now all the bushes are dancing to allow him, looming under him in the sparks of thunder. As he jumps over roots, the ribbon holding the Crown of the Kingdom gets snagged, and he's almost embraced, but the ribbon finally unfastens, and the golden crown vanishes into the sand. Clambering backward, he listens for a tunnel out, but the bushes have unchained him, their thorny bases reaching up to tickle him. He whispers down at the morning until his voice is present. With a sudden stillness, another thunderclap emerges, and suddenly the bushes are back where they've never been. Clarence is standing gloveless and smooth in a sandy lake, gazing down at the clouds and singing. His gloved hand taps onto grass, and Clarence spins to watch to his left, a smaller, cobblestone path. Clarence peers up at his sandy, swollen hands, and with that, the women start tiptoeing up the smaller path. Clarence and Graham recline at adjacent sides of the sofa, with Denise and Margaret on the edge. Although Clarence possesses a large glass of water in front of him, he hasn't sipped it. He's drained from the climb upward but committed to maintain the love song recital. The other four sip gracefully, each plink and drop of a spoon or straw echoing. Graham eventually breaks the stillness, and as Graham drinks out another gulp of lemonade, Clarence abruptly whispers, and all four pause to contemplate. He frowns. She tries to imagine, but it's already here. Margaret gestures, asking if it’s okay for her to stand on the chair, and he shrugs. She nods, and a brief pause follows. Then, expressionless, Clarence rubs his chin, why not. Margaret arrives, heading up the stairs to get her suitcase. We stay with Clarence on the floor as he chuckles, a wave of relief showing that away from everyone he's displaying how little it heals, but together it's clear how good it isn't.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Mildred interrupts Edward to dance, but it's hard to hear over the music. Edward stops, moves through the crowd, and walks down Main Street. The townspeople, disbelieving, believe Edward Bloom has gone crazy. Jenny tries to stop him, but he continues. Barefoot, he struggles through thorns, then encounters moving trees. Roots grab his ankles, but he escapes by swinging between branches. The trees close in, almost strangling him with his chain, which breaks, losing the Key to the City. Trapped and surrounded, he screams, but then the trees reset as if nothing happened. Lying in the mud, Edward laughs and steps onto asphalt, finding a paved road. Edward, Will, Sandra, and Josephine sit awkwardly at the dinner table; though Edward has food, he hasn't touched it. Exhausted, he maintains the family ritual. Will breaks the silence, and Edward suddenly speaks, capturing attention. Josephine asks to sit on the bed, and he nods. She leaves for her camera, and Edward grimaces, revealing the pain he hides from others, showing how much it really hurts.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: We stay with Edward in bed as he grimaces a flash of pain showing that around others he is hiding how much it hurts but alone it is clear how bad it is Josephine leaves heading down the hall to get her camera why not Edward rolls his eyes Then deadpan She shakes her head and a long beat passes Josephine motions asking if it is okay for her to sit on the bed and he nods He tries to recollect but it is already gone She smiles Will finally breaks the silence and as Will scoops out another serving of potatoes Edward suddenly speaks and all three stop to listen The other three eat awkwardly each clink and scrape of a knife or fork resonating He is exhausted from the trip downstairs but determined to maintain the family dinner ritual Although Edward has a small plate of food in front of him he has not touched it Edward and Will sit at opposite ends of the table with Sandra and Josephine in the middle Edward looks down at his muddy bloody feet and with that the men start walking down the larger road His bare foot steps onto asphalt and Edward turns to see to his right a larger paved road Edward is lying shoeless and torn in a muddy puddle staring up at the rain and laughing With a sudden calm another lightning flash occurs and suddenly the trees are back where they have always been He screams up at the night until his breath is gone Scrambling forward he looks for a way out but the trees have encircled him their spiky crowns bending down to crush him As he ducks under branches the chain holding the Key to the City gets caught and he is almost strangled but the chain finally breaks and the silver key disappears into the mud Now all the trees are moving to block him towering over him in the flashes of lightning He leaps up kicking off one tree trunk to grab another one's branches and swings off lands and rolls Snakelike white roots shoot out of the ground grabbing for his ankles they are trying to block him The trees ahead are moving and at first it just seems to be the wind blowing the branches but as the wood cracks and groans it is unmistakable In various shots Edward negotiates the thorns in his bare feet which is horrible and almost unendurable and then it gets worse Jenny runs to him and would tackle him if she could but Edward keeps walking The townspeople stop dancing disbelieving and some shaking their heads saying poor Edward Bloom's gone crazy Edward stops dancing and after a brief moment he heads for the edge of the crowd walking down Main Street Mildred cuts in to dance with Edward but it is hard to hear over the music
